title: ZMR250 ESC Saver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Please note the license these are posted under. You should not download this design to produce for profit. Consider this a BETA design. Any and all feedback welcome.
The thought behind this design is that it goes between the front Arms and ESC's. If they get hit they will absorb some of the impact and improve the chances that your ESC's won't be damaged. These have not been tested. There are 2 designs. ESC Saver (No LED).stl’ - This design does not have the LED slot.
ESC Saver (LED).stl - This design has a 2.9 x 5.7 mm slot to put an LED strip into. The lights will shine through the grid. This design contains 2 models (Left and Right). After printing a test of this I found the slot for the LED was a little too small so I opened it up by .4mm. I have updated the file and am printing another test to validate sizing of the slot. Both designs have 2 slots for Tie Wraps to go through. Weight is about 2.3 grams each. Note that you will need support under the tab that goes between the arm and ESC but you do not want support inside the grid.

comments.text:

After a few experiments with unicorn and laser etching, I remixed my previous design. Haven't made this yet, but gearing up to do so now. There are two ways to make this: Use a Unicorn pen to etch-resist a PCB
Use a Laser or LaserUnicorn ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6846 ) to etch a resist off a PCB

There are a few options for making this, depending on what you have UNICORN etch-resist method
  • Use a fine-tipped sharpie to trace the included file. Use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5986 to generate g-code from the included SVG
  • Put in heated pcb-etch resist until copper is dissolved.
  • Rinse thoroughly, use acetone or turpentine to remove sharpie
    • LASERUNICORN etch method
  • Spray-paint your PCB with black spray paint (or tediously use a sharpie by hand to create a layer)
  • Use the included -Laser.gcode file to burn 6 at once!

I am trying to figure out also the type of attachment i will need to mount to dremel.. and sort out what speed i want to grind at.. I figure once i have a good jig.. it should be fairly quick process.. I am considering contacting the manufacterer, whom is in china.. about possiblity getting it replaced.. but that cud be more work than it's worth.. title: uFluid chip experiment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is for a prototype microFluidic digital mixer. For details about how these devices operate: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_microfluidics
http://microfluidics.ee.duke.edu/
http://www.liquid-logic.com/technology.html No clue if this is going to work yet. ABS is hydrophillic, this might change the implementation or require a catalyst to convert to hydrophobic. The included .scad let's you specify different PCB and dielectric thicknesses. Ideas for bottom electrode:
PCB
Unicorn-drawn on holder with conductive pen Ideas for dielectric: Acrylic sheet
PCB
printed dielectric (thickness will be an issue here) Ideas for top electrode:
Al foil
Sn foil
un-etched PCB
Unicorn-drawn on spacer with conductive pen

Use .scad to customize to the materials you're using and their thicknesses.
Print a holder and spacer.  The spacer and electrodes are 2-symmetric, meaning you can rotate them 180 degrees but not 90 degrees and end up with the same mechanical construction.  The boards are slightly taller than they are wide to assist in assembly.
Create bottom and top electrodes using your method of choice.  UFDMixer.gcode should work for a unicorn based etch-resist pen.  uFluidChip-Laser.gcode should work for a Laser-Unicorn resist etch.
Assemble.
Connect to arduino and program (open source driver coming soon!)

This may not be an instantly obvious fix but....
.
We live in a house that's nearly 200yrs old... and some of the amenities are slightly dated. One of the ways you notice is that modern toilet seat covers don't quite work as well as they perhaps should.
.
Imagine being a gent going to the loo... you lift the seat with your Mrs in mind... as your mother taught you (she'd be ever so proud). And then... right as you "get going" the worst imaginable thing happens... The seat starts to descend towards your "stream"... and we all know what would happen if you let it go... PANIC!
.
This happened to me nearly every trip to the white room... And this is the solution. I took out the old "large" bumpers, and printed some smaller ones. Now the angle of the seat is such that it stays comfortably put!
.
To clarify... The smaller bumpers in the seat cover make it so the seat (in the up position) leans back just a tiny bit more.. and doesn't drop down on it's own.

title: Minimized heavy duty printable filament spool

description.text:
The concept is based on the "Heavy duty printable filament spool", but I re-modelled everything from scratch. The problem with the source one is that -
  • the dovetail keeps breaking. I recount I actually had 3 arms broke at the same point. So I made it bigger, much bigger. And adding a flap so that pressure could be relieved that side too.
  • The holder arm is oversized. I reduced it to almost half of it, and it still overly hard for the job. The length is cut of a bit because of the new attachment design. Result? Faster print time.
    • The axis is designed to be fit with a 608 bearing - which I have a lot laying around. I guess most people do. Arm length:
  • Far end to center - 200mm.
  • Holder base to center: 150mm.
    • I printed it with 50% infill, the dovetail has a good fits - which could be too loose on a very accurate printer.

comments.text: I made one of these last night. It was a huge pain to wind things on to the spool without them getting tangled, but once I got it on there it holds perfectly. The thing press-fits together great too!

description.text: Voronoi remix, one has a base, the other none
Meshlab
for home made box camera

If you print this test, please comment below with what material and gcode you used and what the best temperature was. Description:
3 + 3 different GCODE files for Ultimaker 2 made with the default CURA settings and temperature range from 220C tot 190C in steps of 5C. Printing features:
Straight wall
Overhang (circular)
Overhang (45 degrees)
Curved surface
Flat surface
Hole (for small bridge test)
Rounded corner Fast Print (FP): 0H45, 0.15mm layers
Normal Print (NP): 2H01, 0.10mm layers
High Quality (HQ): 3H21, 0.06mm layers I left the buildplate on 60C because the base was warping with the buildplate heating off. I also included files where the buildplate temperature is set to 0. This is obviously more accurate for the test, but well, if the base of the print comes loose you sort of have nothing. You can try for yourself. If you want to make the gcode yourself or for a different printer, you'll have to insert the temperature commands yourself at the appropriate layer. The base is 2mm high, the rest is 10mm per piece. Commands: Set bed temp to 0:
M140 S0 Set nozzle temperature:
M104 S200
(where 200 is the temperature). USE THESE GCODE FILES AT YOUR OWN RISK AND ONLY ON ULTIMAKER 2

Load the gcode in your UM 2 to start the test. Look at the results and decide what temperature works best for your material.
Different layer heights result in different extrusion rates, so optimal temperatures might be different for the differtent cura print presets.
If you want to print using Cura Fast Print, you need to do the fast print test.

description.text: Another Spiral Cup, this one with the links going around the cup

Generate an STL using a Mac and then print Update
I created a simplified version so that I could generate the STL file, it's a little too large to print, please scale by 0.75 to fit the build platform of a Makerbot. I also moved the loop up to the mid point to reduce the overhang (that's the blue one printed) I've tried to use parameters for everything you might want to change: axisRotation the number of times around the top of the torus
radialRotation the number of times rotated into the hole in the torus
baseHeight height of the plinth (0 for no plinth)
numberOfSpheres number of spheres used to complete the knot
sphereQuality the larger the number, the lower the quality see $fs
majorRadius the major radius of the torus
minorRadius the minor radius of the torus
sphereSize the size of each dot in the knot
cupHeight number of links high
vStretchFor3dPrint how much to stretch it up to help with overhang
printWidthInMM the width you'd like the finished item to be in millimetres This is based on the Parametric Knot thing I made previously, ...and the bracelet thing (notice a theme, I promise I'll stop soon :) I had to do the knot thing before I could produce the cup I wanted, and it turned out nicely, so I published it.

description.text: The World really needs another filament holder. This one lacks anything special, but does bolt to the existing plate and support my big reels of ABS. The reel axle is 10 degrees off horizontal so that no clips are necessary to hold the reel on - gravity works reliably enough. The angle also puts the weight over the vertical support rendering any support on the other side of the reel unnecessary. Just bolt to the acrylic plate with the wooden spacer removed. It is just possible that the reel might interfere with a very tall print that sits at the very back of the bed....I am sure someone else could do better.

remixed_from.title: tosjduenfs' Cable Chain With Rounded Edges

description.text:
Check out this awesome video for help: http://youtu.be/B2NtvZyca5A
Install the cable chain without replacing the carriage. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1066680 This is my solution to attaching a cable chain to the ROBO 3D R1.
Warning! Some ingenuity and basic electronic skills required. You will run into obstacles when installing this new carriage.
Removing the bearings from the old carriage into the new one can be tricky. I taped them out with a hammer and screwdriver (The handle needs to be able to fit through the hole in the carriage not the bearing. If the bearings do not fit snug do not worry. Just add some tape around the bearing until it fits tight. I hope you find this useful and as much fun as I did!!!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium-High

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:   Material: PLA

You will need a total of 38 chain links.     The process my vary depending on the version of the ROBO 3D R1 you have so I am going to outline the things I had to do.     1. Disassemble the carriage      2. Apply two layers of tape around bearing to get it to fit snug in new  carriage.     3. Un-solder the x axis sensor in order to run the cable through the chain.     4. Drill a hole in the carriage for the x axis sensor.  (In the V2 version this is already done)     5. Feed the cables through in sections of four links at a time one cable at a time.     6. Drill four holes in the shell of the ROBO 3D for the bolts that hold on the link connector.     Make sure you test everything as you go!!     Have Fun!!  :)

description.text: This is a drivenut that can be milled from a piece of delrin (or pom or acetal or hdpe or...) that fits the trapezium thread I use in my mantis version. Of course, this part can be milled on the mantis itself, another step for self reproduction.

Bolt together with 20 mm (or perhaps 16) 3m bolts or similar. The A part has slightly larger bolt holes, so insert the bolts in the back of that part.

author: koelewijn_w

title: Miband Band Extension Plate - to register activity when cycling and using similar gym equipment

description.text:
The Xiaomi Miband is a popular low cost health band (i.e. wearable technology). Users may want this simple band extension foruse when cycling or at the gym using an exercycle (or similar).
Like most health bands the Miband features a pedometer (plus a range of other features including monitoring sleep etc.) and is usually attached around your wrist and functions through movement. So how does it track steps?
When you walk or run your arms swing and these devices register that movement... not steps. This is okay in many instances but one common form of exercise that these do not register is cycling or exercise on similar equipment where arm movement is not adequate to record a 'step' regardless of the physical exersion.
The simple solution is to attach the band to your ankle when exercising this way. The problem is, unless you have small ankles, the band is too short. These simple extensions will allow you to securely wear a Miband on your ankle so you can register every leg rotation as a step.
As ankles can differ in size quite significantly there are four .stl's provided to suit S / M / L / XL ankles. The difference between sizes is 7.5mm in length which is equivalent to one adjustment on the Miband strap. Approx. extension lengths are as follows: S = 15mm
M = 25mm
L = 30mm
XL = 35mm But remember you can still use the standard holes in conjunction with this so pick the one that is about what you need from the middle hole on your standard band. This small plate will print in just a few minutes to provide far more accurate Miband activity monitoring thereafter. Note: I expect the same issues exist with most other health bands so the same concept could be applied.
This is a small but practical print for Xiaomi Miband users. Print with PLA / Raft / Std (0.20mm) resolution / 3 shells / 35% fill.

So you have one of the brightest flashlights in the world and would like to build a projector from it? Look no further! Combine it with the gBeam slide holder and some lens, and you are ready to go! Caveat: The flashlight can become very hot after some time. When hot, the plastic will soften, and structural integrity of the part is no longer guaranteed.

Print this strong and in high resolution (0.1mm layers).
High resolution is needed for the fine pitch threads of the flashlight.
100% fill is recommended for optimal stability. For better performance you can cover the inside with reflecting paint (for example silver spray paint).

This is a customisable version of the pen holder arms used by EggBots (http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/productsmenu/51-accessories/205-distalarm). It was designed to be a solid, one piece object without any nuts and bolts for holding it together. It actually turned out to be 2 pieces glued together, as it's easier and faster to print this way. To allow fitting different kinds of pens (for example Sharpie Ultrafine and Sharpie Fine markers), the pen arm itself contains a hole for an pen adaptor module. This way, when you want to change pens, you only need to replace the adaptor with another one and you get a tight fit on any pen of yours. I supplied STLs for adaptors for the ultrafine Sharie and for the fine-point Sharpie. If you want to use a custom pen, a configurable OpenSCAD file is available where you can change the diameters around. The OpenSCAD file also allows the customization of various parameters, like the length of the arm, the thickness of the piece and the diameter of the bolt fixing the pen. Extra parts needed:
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 1x M3 bolt
    • Compatible with Basic, Deluxe and Ostrich EggBots. You can use the same S90 TowerPro servo on this arm as on the one you got from EvilMadScientist. Update 1 @ 2015-04-12

• increased the thickness of the "thin part" of the pen arm from one layer thickness (0.2mm) to two layer thickness (0.4mm) to increase durability
  • modified the OpenSCAD script printing the pen adaptors so that you can specify the to diameter and bottom diameter of the adaptor module in order to model the shape of the pen better.
  • updated the ultra fine sharpie STL to have better dimensions

The supplied STL files have been generated from the OpenSCAD file. They are configured for a standard EggBot, for use with an M3 bolt and nut as pen fixers and contain adaptors for the ultrafine Sharpie and the fine Sharpie markers.
  • Print all STL files
  • Glue the "stepper arm" and the "pen arm" together
  • Put an M3 nut into the shaft designed for it, found on the inside of the hole for the pen adaptor on the pen arm
  • Insert the pen adapter (fine.stl and ultrafine.stl) into the hole designed for them on the pen arm
    • Pretty straightforward. If you want to customize it, take a look at the SCAD file, it even has comments. The most important settings in it:
  • l1: size of the stepper arm
  • l2: size of the pen arm
  • thickness: thickness of the arms
  • gap: gap to leave between objects that should fit into each other. For printers that are not 100% exact. Like mine.
  • screwDiameter: diameter of the bolt fixing the pen in its place.
  • nutDiameter: diameter of the nut for holding the bolt
  • nutThickness: size of the shaft to house the nut
  • diameter parameter for the penHolder() module: Diameter of the pen to print an adapter for.
    • At the end of the OpenSCAD file you will find module calls that you can comment out to obtain the specific parts you want.

title: Mini Kossel j-head mount with 40mm PEEK fan and dual 40mm layer fans

description.text: Mini Kossel j-head mount with 40mm PEEK fan and dual 40mm layer fans. This was partially inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:560992 I was having difficulty finding the high speed 30mm fans required for that design for anything less than about £20 each. This is a modified version of the Think3dPrint3d (http://think3dprint3d.com/Kossel-Mini-3dPrinter-Kit) design. This is a work in progress, having played with the design for a few days I'm considering using blowers instead, as the regular fans do not create a huge amount airflow at the nozzle. Obviously switching to blower (squirrelcage) fans will require a completely different design e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:711090

I've only printed a previous version, this version should need similar support.  
Sliced with Cura at 0.2 mm layer height, support touching everywhere, no platform adhesion should be required.

comments.text: The walls of the air ducts for the two side fans are very thin - too thin for Simplify3D to bother printing them; it slices a lot of these walls as retract-open space.  This makes the print essentially unprintable at 0.4mm nozzle width as there are literally thousands of retractions over these thin areas.

A clip-in cup holder I made for a colleague's wheel chair. Top Clip may need some filing to slide into the frame. Two sizes of bottom clip provided (his chair's down pipe was a bit angled and a longer one was needed). Bottom clip should be glued or plastic welded to the frame. Top clip should stay just fine with friction, but can be glued if needed. Use a self-tapping screw to fix cup holder cup to the frame with the fastener. The cup can be rotated and then fastened to take into account that the top pipe on the chair would be slightly angled. Mirroring everything should make this a left hand model. FreeCAD file included (it's a bit of a mess, but it's all there!) Edit:
Added an improved bottom clip that can be fastened with a screw and is more bendable.

author: sekmen14

description.text:
This set of short GCode scripts initiates what I hope will be a longstanding practice of creating fun things for your bot to do. Nothing as heavy as extruding much. More dances, gestures, sounds, and neat tricks. These scripts play well on all MakerBots (I don't play favorites: Thing-O-Matics and Cupcakes are both invited to the party). Make sure to read the instructions at the top of the code before running each partymode. Your axes might be reversed in a different pattern than mine -- so watch out! Where are your partymode scripts? And quick utilities? And stupid pranks? Making these things is probably the best way out there to get a firm grasp on essential, human-readable g-code scripting. They always told me that the future would be fun. And so I made it fun for everyone. Included in this set: "Game Anthem Grrarr!"
"MakerBot M Stamper!"
"one turn deserves another"
"Party like a cube"
"sNAKEy dANCe"
"Stirring the Air"
"Triangle Man, Triangle Man"
"Where Is Violin! Is Too So Small!" Thanks to Pleasant 3D for the great gcode path visualization ... for these behaviors that leave no extrusion trace upon the world. (http://bit.ly/dUe5xh)

Here is how you do it:
  • Download partymode scripts.
  • Schedule the party. Invite friends and bot-friends.
  • Place the text files into a folder titled "partymode" that you create in the "scripts" folder in ReplicatorG 24.
  • Order party hats. Catering. Don't forget extra ice and 3-IN-ONE oil. (Especially the oil!)
  • Fire up ReplicatorG 24. Pick a partymode script here: "File > scripts > partymode"
  • Guests arrive!
  • Read the instructions on the code. (But where is the ASCII art? lazy-mifga)
  • Offer some 3-IN-ONE oil to your botfriends.
  • Build the script!
  • Party!
  • M30
    • As requested, I added a zip file! (I've tested these scripts on two Cupcakes and two Thing-O-Matics - but read instructions in scripts carefully so you can take advantage of the absolute positioning magic!)

author: Fixator

description.text:
I bought these fancy brand name windscreen wipers.
However they do not make enough preassure on the windscreen allways leaving a pool of water in the middle of the windshield. This wing is made to put preassure on the wiper arm and is enough to get the job done! Update:
The model has been updated to have the curve on the opposit side to catch more air, making it work even at slower speeds. It's also thinner and looks better.
Now it uses only 7,85cm3 of model material! Update 2:
Ive added a 10cm model designed to use no support! Works -really- well. This project was made possible by www.protech.se!

Best way to print it is standing up, look at the insight picture i uploaded.
This is to make the fittings strong. Unfortionetly this means that the modell will need support to print. This was made for my Golf4, but it's still a universal design, so it will most likley fit your car aswell. If it does not you can just scale it a little bit to make it fit, but make it snug so it will stay on even when the wipers are on the highest setting. The MakerBot's tend to put a little more plastics on the model than the Dimension/Fortus machines, this in turn will make the dimensions of the MakerBot parts slightly off, so you might need to play around with the scaling option a few times.

comments.text: my '02 legacy came with a "wing" on the driver's side wiper. i think it was factory, but i bought the car second-hand, and i scrapped it last year. it was more cupped, sort of wing-shaped, and seemed to also direct the airflow upwards towards the centre of the windshield.
comments.author: wildthang

comments.text: I've actually learned a thing or two about these since I posted this, and basically it's impossible to make a universal definetly working one. One model can work for one car at some speeds but be crap on another and so on. I'm still leaving this up because it helped me once so it might help at least some body else :P

title: Nicotine - OpenSCAD generated from chemical SDF files

description.text:
Molecule structure STL files are generated by OpenSCAD, of which program is generated by "sdf2scad.perl" Perl script from NCBI PubChem database (3D SDF format files). About generating scripts and note, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:689652 (Water and Ethanol). Bad health for your 3D printer!! Nicotine (C10H14N2) causes many diseases and reduces the health blah blah blah...
Construction 3D data (SDF file) is from the PubChem Project https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ .
See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:689652 (Water and Ethanol) for detail.

comments.text: how did you print it? did you use supports?
comments.author: htmlmarine

comments.text:
Of course I added supports by the slicer.
Removing them is another story - I used files and hand grinder.
To avoid breaking the thinnest bar ("hydrogen bond"), scaling at least x5-x10 is suggested. I used x8 scale, then the biggest & most instable "vitamin E" keeps its form and has certain strength with ABS (see picture of vitamin E).
On some points printer fails to make thin bar, or I broke bar when removing supports, but I used acetone to melt & reconnect it (better than glue).
comments.author: htmlmarine

author: taroh

title: Cabagin - OpenSCAD generated from chemical SDF files

description.text:
Molecule structure STL files are generated by OpenSCAD, of which program is generated by "sdf2scad.perl" Perl script from NCBI PubChem database (3D SDF format files). About generating scripts and note, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:689652 (Water and Ethanol). Cabagin (aka MMSC - S-methylmethionine or Vitamin U, C6H15NO2S) is a nice digestive medicine, originally extracted from cabbage, and I sometimes use when overeaten. :-) It's ionized, so I added Cl- ion in the STL data.
Construction 3D data (SDF file) is from the PubChem Project https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ .
See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:689652 (Water and Ethanol) for detail.

description.text:
A propeller with blades curved in two planes. Nosecone is hollow. Features square central hole for mounting on peg for rotational movement transmission and cross hole for a locking pin. All edges are filleted to various radii. Three levels of detail are included respectively with : verts : 32813, 120424, 305251
trigs : 65626, 240848, 610502 Side of the square hole is 15 mm. Central hub is 45 mm in diametre. Locking pin hole is 6.5 mm in diametre. Fillet radius of the edges of the square central hole are 2 mm for the lateral edges and 1 mm for the bottom edges.
Created using Autodesk 123D Design and Meshlab.

comments.text: Hello i have a question:
comments.author: Flautarian

comments.text: I don't know. The idea behind the scimitar blade, curved in two planes, is to have the blade's effective angle of attack gradually decrease as you go further away from the center of the propeller while still retaining a uniform curvature to the blade. This is because the linear velocity of the blade is greater the farther away from the center you go so you actually want the angle of attack to be shallower to reduce drag and stress on the propeller blades.
comments.author: Flautarian

Stanford d.school Z-Board

2013 Southeast con robot. This robot will be full open source, but until Saturday morning 4/6/13 the files will not be open to public, ;)  
So bad news, we lost.  Yup, in the process of losing we developed a new term for amature mistakes.  "Revpol" this is defined as apply voltage backwards, or reverse polarization.   
Anyway, we will be uploading all source code soon along with a BOM.  In the meantime until the team is ready to upload everything I will answer questions regarding the build in the comments as to get people going.

So we posted some singled out items for you. But for the most part the entire sketchup file is available and parts can be picked and exported in a singular fashion. Tank tracks:
These were printed, but I had to dremel out a nice amount of material to create a bevel for the sprocket gear to enter and exit the linkage without bindage.
I used a drill bit to clear the holes keeping all holes in the tracks consistent at around 3 mm-3.1 mm whatever drill bit you have. I then used cut pieces of polycarbonate 3mm longer the the tracks are wide. Insert and use a lighter to get the end hot and then use the lighter to push the rod in the tracks "mushing" the soft plastic and creating a riveting effect. The repeat on the other side. Leave one link where this is not done on the outer side; this is your master link. ABS should work just fine.

title: Post-it holder for platform levelling calibration

description.text:
This handle makes it easy to reach deeply into the 3D printer while calibrating and levelling the build platform. It is designed to hold a standard Post-it sticky paper on it's tip. By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

In most cases the optimal gap between a 3D printer's platform and the extruder's hot-end tip, is 0,1 mm. A common practice is to use a simple sheet of paper and place it on top of the build platform just under the extruder's tip.
The platform is then adjusted so that the paper slightly touches the tips of the extruder. The adjustment must be made on all corners and the centre of the build plate until it is perfectly level.
â€¢ Download the STL file
â€¢ 3D-print it
â€¢ Grab a Post-it sticky of your preferred colour
â€¢ Stick it on the flat front end of the 3D-printed handle
â€¢ Set-up you 3D-printer for levelling the platform
â€¢ Place the paper between the the platform and the extruder tip
â€¢ Adjust the build plate's screws and move the handle slightly to make the paper slide under the extruder tip
â€¢ When you feel a slight friction stop adjusting the screw
â€¢ Repeat this process on all corners and centre of the platform until you can feel the same friction on all spots
Make sure that you only use one sheet of Post-it paper and if unsure control-measure it with a calliper to verify 0.1 mm thickness.
After calibrating your Replicator's platform it should remain level for a long time.
Until you need to calibrate it next time you can use this Post-it handle for other purposes as follows:
â€¢ A very gentle fly-swat
â€¢ A small sign holder you can use to communicate short messages to your office mates

title: Float Valve Receiver for Food Rising Mini-Farm Grow Box

description.text:
This float valve receiver is part of the float valve assembly that controls water levels in the Food Rising Mini-Farm Grow Box, a revolutionary non-electric grow system developed by the Health Ranger. All 3D parts are downloadable from FoodRising.org which also includes assembly instructions and DIY videos. This object requires a hole of 15mm in diameter for mounting, and it mounts to the side wall of the grow container, approximately 2-1/2" above the bottom of the container. The complete float valve also requires the printing of the Float Valve Adapter and the Retention Nut. How to Successfully 3D Print This Part: Approximate print time = 18 minutes
Filament: Taulman T-glase, any color
Print temperature: 250C
Bed temperature: 0C - 70C
Nozzle size: 0.5mm - 0.7mm (0.4mm nozzle is too small to print t-glase)
Layer height: 0.35mm (do not go below 0.3mm)
Print speed: 25 - 40 mm/s (use 50% for first layer)
Filament flow rate: 90% - 94%
Infill: 100% DO NOT use ABS or PLA. The model will be too fragile.

title: Printrbot Power Tower alternative (Plexi Power Tower)

description.text: I just upgraded my Printrbot Simple Metal with a heated bed and now that it has an ugly ATX PSU attached to it I wanted a way to hide it. Printrbot sells a "Metal Power Tower" but its $60!!! This is an alternative to house the PSU out of site and also hold a reel of filament on top (will roll freely on bearing or metal rods). I plan on getting some black plexiglass to match my black Printrbot. Everything in the picture that is white I plan to print. I may need to print some more internal supports for the PSU itself, but we'll see how it goes. UPDATE: 6/6/15 - started to print parts and attach plexiglass together. Pic updated as well

Holes in brackets are for 4-40 screws. I plan on using 1/8" plexi and 1/2" screws. The two larger holes in each filament bracket are 9mm. Im hoping to put a rod for the filament real to rest on and roll freely.

These surfaces and skins were constructed in pure openSCAD, thanks to support for computation provided in versions since late 2014. The code is on Github https://github.com/KitWallace/openscad/blob/master/poly_surface.scad and the project is discussed in my blog http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/111959789244/computed-surfaces-in-openscad http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24897 also constructs surfaces but because it uses unions of small cuboids, it is rather slower. Be aware that there is no check on sanity so faces can be reversed with dire effects on subsequent CSG operations.

description.text:
A bracket for mounting the Y-axis endstop packaged with gen4 electronics onto a Cupcake CNC.
Extra mounting holes are there just in case the friction grip is not adequate.

Skeinforge has been giving me trouble with objects that have walls less than 2.5mm thick.  Removing the extra shells in the FILL plugin definitely improves the quality of thin walled objects, but there is still some strange activity going on near the thru holes.  For thicker parts, I keep the extra shells at 2, the same as the default profile.

This is a hanging planter for an air plant.  Please scale as necessary for the plant you buy - the pic I have here is 1.5 times scale.  
Make one? Be sure to take a picture and share it! 
Enjoy!

You will have to guesstimate what scale you need to print at for the air plant you buy.  I'd recommend buying the plant first and going from there.  You can also carefully carve out a bit of the hole with a utility blade.  
To assemble this, tie a piece of fishing line around the base of the air plant, slide the two ends of the line through the top hole, and slowly lower the octopus onto the air plant.  
The bottom hole is designed to allow you to angle the air plant backwards like the octopus is swimming or straight down.
